legislations.title: Migration Act 1958
legislations.description: The primary legislation governing migration to, from and within Australia. It establishes the framework for immigration control, visa processing, deportation procedures, and the rights and obligations of non-citizens.
legislations.full_text:
AN ACT to provide for and in relation to the entry into, and residence in, Australia of non-citizens, and for purposes connected with the foregoing.

Part 1 - Preliminary

1. Short title
This Act may be cited as the Migration Act 1958.

2. Commencement
This Act shall come into operation on such date as the Governor-General, by proclamation, appoints.

Part 2 - Interpretation

3. Definitions
In this Act, unless the contrary intention appears:
'approved form' means a form approved in writing by the Minister;
'Australia' includes the external Territories;
'citizen' means an Australian citizen;
'non-citizen' means a person who is not an Australian citizen;
'visa' means a permission granted to a non-citizen to be in Australia.

Part 3 - Visas

4. Visa requirements
A non-citizen must hold a valid visa to enter and remain in Australia, unless specifically exempted.

5. Classes of visas
The Minister may specify the following classes of visas:
(a) Protection visas
(b) Skilled migration visas
(c) Family reunion visas
(d) Temporary visas
(e) Special category visas

Part 4 - Deportation and Removal

6. Grounds for deportation
The Minister may cancel a visa and deport a non-citizen on specified grounds including:
(a) Security concerns
(b) Health grounds
(c) Character grounds
(d) Visa condition breaches
(e) Criminal convictions

Part 5 - Administrative Appeals

7. Review of decisions
A non-citizen may seek review of visa decisions through the Migration Review Tribunal or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Part 6 - Refugee and Humanitarian

8. Refugee Convention
This Act gives effect to Australia's obligations under the 1951 Refugee Convention and Protocol.

legislations.title: Migration Regulations 1994
legislations.description: Subordinate legislation made under the Migration Act 1958. Sets out detailed procedures, requirements, and criteria for visa applications, processing, and administrative decisions related to migration.
legislations.full_text:
MIGRATION REGULATIONS 1994
Made under the Migration Act 1958

Part 1 - Preliminary

1. Short title
These Regulations may be cited as the Migration Regulations 1994.

2. Commencement
These Regulations commence on [date].

Part 2 - Interpretation

3. Definitions
In these Regulations:
'visa' has the same meaning as in the Act;
'eligible family member' means a member of the family as defined in Schedule 1;
'points test' means the assessment system for skilled migration visas.

Part 3 - Application Requirements

4. Form of applications
Applications must be made in an approved form and must include:
(a) Personal details of the applicant
(b) Details of family members
(c) Evidence of identity
(d) Health and character assessments

Part 4 - Skilled Migration

5. Points requirements
For skilled migration visas, applicants must achieve the minimum points score based on:
(a) Age (maximum 45 points)
(b) English language (maximum 20 points)
(c) Skilled employment (maximum 20 points)
(d) Qualifications (maximum 25 points)

Part 5 - Family Migration

6. Sponsorship requirements
Family reunion visas require a citizen or permanent resident sponsor who must:
(a) Be at least 18 years old
(b) Pass a character test
(c) Meet financial requirements

Part 6 - Health and Character

7. Health assessments
Applicants must undergo health assessments by approved panel doctors.

8. Character requirements
Applicants must be of good character and not have serious criminal convictions.

legislations.title: Australian Citizenship Act 2007
legislations.description: Legislation that governs the acquisition, loss, and cessation of Australian citizenship. Establishes pathways to citizenship and criteria for maintaining citizenship status.
legislations.full_text:
AN ACT relating to Australian citizenship.

Part 1 - Preliminary

1. Short title
This Act may be cited as the Australian Citizenship Act 2007.

Part 2 - Citizenship by Descent

2. Citizenship by descent
A person may be an Australian citizen by descent if:
(a) Their parent was an Australian citizen at the time of their birth; or
(b) Their parent acquired Australian citizenship by descent from an Australian citizen.

Part 3 - Citizenship by Conferral

3. Citizenship by conferral
The Minister may confer Australian citizenship on a person who:
(a) Is at least 18 years old
(b) Has been a permanent resident for at least 4 years
(c) Intends to reside in Australia
(d) Has knowledge of English
(e) Is of good character
(f) Demonstrates commitment to Australia

Part 4 - Loss and Cessation

4. Renunciation
An Australian citizen may renounce their citizenship by making a declaration.

5. Cessation
Citizenship ceases if a person acquires citizenship of another country.

Part 5 - Citizenship Tests

6. Citizenship test requirements
Applicants for citizenship must pass a test demonstrating knowledge of:
(a) Australian history
(b) Rights and responsibilities of citizenship
(c) Government and democracy in Australia
(d) The Australian Constitution

legislations.title: Migration Agents Registration Act 1994
legislations.description: Legislation establishing a registration system for migration agents in Australia. Sets out professional standards, ethics, and procedures for regulatory oversight of agents who provide migration assistance.
legislations.full_text:
AN ACT relating to the registration of migration agents.

Part 1 - Preliminary

1. Short title
This Act may be cited as the Migration Agents Registration Act 1994.

Part 2 - Interpretation

2. Definitions
'migration agent' means a person who gives immigration advice or represents a person in migration matters;
'immigration advice' includes advice about Australian migration law.

Part 3 - Registration

3. Registration requirement
A person must not give immigration advice or represent a person in migration matters unless they:
(a) Are registered as a migration agent; or
(b) Are exempt from registration.

4. Exemptions
The following are exempt:
(a) Lawyers practising as lawyers
(b) Employees of government agencies
(c) Relatives acting without fee

Part 4 - Conduct and Discipline

5. Code of Conduct
Registered migration agents must:
(a) Act honestly and with integrity
(b) Treat clients fairly
(c) Maintain confidentiality
(d) Keep proper records
(e) Not engage in misleading conduct

6. Complaints
Complaints about migration agents may be made to the Commissioner.

Part 5 - Termination of Registration

7. Grounds for termination
Registration may be terminated for:
(a) Breach of Code of Conduct
(b) Dishonesty or fraud
(c) Incompetence
(d) Failure to comply with obligations

legislations.title: Protection of Borders Act 2015
legislations.description: Legislation that amends the Migration Act 1958 to provide enhanced border control measures, establish regional processing centres, and set out procedures for managing maritime arrivals.
legislations.full_text:
AN ACT to amend the Migration Act 1958 and for related purposes.

Part 1 - Preliminary

1. Short title
This Act may be cited as the Protection of Borders Act 2015.

Part 2 - Regional Processing

2. Regional processing centres
The Minister may establish and maintain regional processing centres for the processing of asylum seekers.

3. Transfer powers
Non-citizens may be transferred to regional processing centres for assessment.

Part 3 - Maritime Powers

4. Maritime patrol
The Minister may authorize the Australian Defence Force to conduct maritime operations.

5. Interception powers
Vessels carrying asylum seekers may be intercepted and diverted.

Part 4 - No Visa on Arrival

6. Exclusion from visa
People who arrive by sea without authority cannot be granted certain visas.

7. Third country resettlement
Asylum seekers may be resettled in third countries.

legislations.title: Family Law Act 1975
legislations.description: Legislation governing family law matters in Australia, including marriage, divorce, and property settlement. Relevant to immigration in contexts involving family-based visa sponsorship and spousal relationships.
legislations.full_text:
AN ACT to establish a court and to provide for the determination by that court of matters arising out of the marital relationship.

Part 1 - Preliminary

1. Short title
This Act may be cited as the Family Law Act 1975.

Part 2 - Jurisdiction

2. Family Court jurisdiction
The Family Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine:
(a) Applications for marriage dissolution
(b) Property settlement disputes
(c) Parenting disputes
(d) Child support matters

Part 3 - Marriage

3. Recognition of marriage
A marriage is valid if solemnized according to law.

4. De facto relationships
De facto relationships have similar recognition to marriage.

Part 4 - Property

5. Property settlement
Upon divorce, property must be divided according to:
(a) Contributions of each party
(b) Future needs
(c) Other relevant factors

Part 5 - Children

6. Parental responsibility
Each parent has responsibility for children until age 18.

7. Child support
Parents must provide financial support for children.
